<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_notify:
```c
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The code passes &val where val is declared as a non-const uint64_t, so the pointer expression has type uint64_t * (a pointer to a non-const object). MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 requires pointers to point to const-qualified types whenever possible; here val is never modified after initialization and could be declared const. This is a violation. Fix: declare val as const uint64_t val = 1; so &val is a pointer-to-const and matches the intent of the rule.
